Hello! I hope to contribute to this repo in the future, so I'm starting to learn it. I've only just started, so I've only looked at it a small amount. I noticed that in Foundation.FirstOrder.SetTheory.Ordinal.lean, Ordinal is defined like this:

@[ext]
structure Ordinal where
  val : V
  ordinal : IsOrdinal val

The definition def Ordinal := {α : V // IsOrdinal α} seems to be equivalent, which would include lemmas about Subtype. However, the line @[ext] would no longer work, and Subtype.eq would have to be used in its place. I'm wondering if this the reason why a structure was used in place of a subtype? (Is it also agreed to be more readable to use a structure instead of a subtype?)

Hi! I avoided using subtype because I wanted to prevent instances outside my control. Of course, it also has the advantage of appearing simpler (at least I follow a policy of generally not using subtype, except for the case related to type theoretic argument).
Thanks, I will keep this in mind!
